Oh absolutely. I started an animation course for this precise reason and it's obvious that animating will force you to consider perspective and proportion with each drawing in order to maintain consistency and will give you a sense of perspective and everything required to draw good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6422640
Yes, but animation requires you to be economical with your linework and detail. This is a double edged sword, because sure it means that you will consider those things more often in your illustrations/paintings and your designs might be stronger for it, or you might gimp yourself and forget how to draw detailed things, or it might force you into a particular style without a clear way out. If everything you draw already looks like a cartoon though then yeah its good to learn animation

pic related, Yoh Yoshinari is both a god-tier animator and a great illustrator. best case scenario

Huge industries, like the entire entertainment business, would risk getting replaced by algorithms. Coorporations might be evil but they still care about self-preservation, not to mention the political implications of millions of people losing their income. Yea it happened to manufacturing and guess what, we are still dealing with the problems it caused to this day. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

i for one have never been a fan of super heavy cross hatching. That's why i prefer the upper branches which are shaded by a series of parallels curves. if this could be done for the entire piece it would be pleasant, some of this "cleanness" is already in the boots too
I would also question only having some parts of the image exist outside the rectangle, since it is only the right but not the left it implies something of where to look which. I am not certain on the choice to have the foreground dissolve into the white at the bottom, when this is done in very close proximity the the main subject matter of the kneeling figure.
the figure on the bottom must be very short, give the apparent distance from waistline to shoulder is less then the forearm. if this is intentional then good.
as for the pose of the figure it is good, but i wonder why it doesn't strike me as super good, well my gut feeling is that the pose of the head does not exactly line up with how the gun is held such that his eyes would be looking down the sites. if anything he seems to be just slighting looking at his own hands. again this is a matter of taste, sure we could imagine a figure super dynamically sprawled out where his body is matches the line of motion of holding the gun, where his back foot is hyper extended along this line of motion, but that would betray the more timid nature of the figure and turn them into a more mythical entity.
Also compare the shading of the upper branches if you squint at those upper branches you can see an almost full gradient between the light and dark with another light at the underside. then if you squint at the at the tree that the serpentine is around it is pretty flat save for the shadow cast by the entity, but its not a hard shadow which is odd, for a shadow cast by an opaque object will be a hard shadow
but i wouldn't modify this drawing anymore,
anyway i think im having a manic episode which is why i wrote so much for no reason

>>6420517
It depends on what you mean by that.
To me there's two definitions, the pejorative and then the descriptive definition.

I remember first hearing the term here back in 2012-2016. The tumblr artstyle in that sense usually referred to drawings that went out of their way to defy conventional beauty standards for the sake of inclusivity(I think?).
I think some of it was also that the artists were also not that studious and didn't want to spend time grinding fundamentals. A lot of them just made fanart and OCs.

Nowadays though I don't see that kinda stuff on tumblr anymore so I don't think it exists in the same capacity as before, but it's also possible that I've just curated my timeline that way because I don't follow artists who make stuff like that.
Now that I think about it even back in 2017 when I was using the site the most I didn't ever really encounter that stuff too often.

saccharine is also a really good way to put it. Pastels and infantilization are other traits I would add to that.

>>6420517
When I think of The Tumblr Artstyle I think of something calarts-inspired, simple in technique but very stylized and quirky. It was all the rage on 2013-2016 tumblr because of Steven Universe presumably but I still see it every now and again, mostly on twitter this time. I never understood the hate for it, I think it's pretty charming. Especially the tumblr nose.

Then there's The Social Justice flavor which focuses on "inclusive" characteristics like leg hair or stretch marks. Understandably it makes the drawings look ugly but I guess that's sort of the point? There's something to be said for people who go out of their way to draw ugly things, it makes this point to capture realism at the cost of appeal. I kind of like it in theory. I always got the feeling it caused such a knee-jerk reaction from people because of the rise of social justice at the time, people were tired of hearing how much of oppressors they were just for having preferences and beauty standards so the artstyle was only pouring salt into the wound. In retrospect I think it's... Well, still ugly but also somewhat interesting.

oh yeah let me trust the abstract of the older study with 0 link to the full thing over the newer fully accessible one

Population based norms for the box and blocks test in healthy right-handed Taiwanese adults (2020)

Some of the effects on dexterity have been suggested to be the results of smaller finger sizes in females compared to males, in tests like the pegboard [38,42,43] but this interpretation is not consistently supported [44]. Given the sex effects on hand preference and on performance task, a systematic analysis on the derived laterality indexes seems justified.

... Also, consistent with previous literature, we found that females outperformed males in dexterity tasks ( pegboard, marking squares and sorting matches) but not in strength (grip strength) tasks [37,40,41] (table 5). Some studies suggested that higher dexterity in females could be influenced by finger size [43], but these observations were limited to the pegboard task and failed to replicate in subsequent studies [44]. We did not have measures of finger sizes in our dataset and therefore could not test this effect directly.

Therapists won't help because I know what my problem is and what I have to do, it's just that the latter is really fucking hard and take a lot of time. I also hate sitting around and just talking about problems I already know about, and I rather not get shitty advice from a therapist who obviously doesn't prioritize the same things I prioritize. I've gotten so many shitty PC advice that I am glad I never listened. Bad advice is worse than no advice.

I am high functioning but I know I am depressed when I can't cough up some drawings. All that time and energy not-drawing, I put that into other aspects of my life.

I have a roof over my head. I have good amount of money. I work out every day and am in great shape. I have a degree and a job at a well known agency. But I am miserable all the time and I no longer have friends. I used to have friends at work. I no longer have friends at work. I barely ever draw either. The problem isn't the lack of meeting people, or the lack of time to draw.

In the meantime I am wondering if drugs will help make my issues more tolerable while I rise above them. I really don't want to, and it will hurt my day job career options because they won't mess with that shit, but sometimes when it's really bad I wonder.

>>6417802
For me SSRI antidepressants were like when you light a bottle rocket but it wasn’t properly staked into the ground so when it shoots off in immediately shoots into the ground and tries to hang itself in the state park neighboring its apartment complex.

If you’re taking ssris and then continuing to be behaviorally (and then cognitively) depressed by sitting around aimlessly staring into a black mirror for ego validation, you’re not likely going to fix anything or “get better.”

I’ve found it’s best to just find a way to extrinsically force yourself to DO ANYTHING and then when you get the plates spinning you can keep things going until the next inevitable crash.

Idk. I don’t believe in SSRIs or their efficacy to relieve a cognitive condition that is overwhelmingly caused by behavioral and environmental variables.

If you want to be less depressed go try to kill yourself from exposure or starvation. Sail a boat out into the middle of the Atlantic during storm season. Find an actual purpose to risk death and suddenly life and production become easy distractions.

Not trying to gatekeeper or discredit. Point is that at a certain point everything comes down to modifying how you think and how that makes you behave.

posts.com:
Tbphwyf I like to make something that gives me aestheticism and engineering feels and make me feel good about myself and feel like I’ve reached a new level on technique or aesthetic theory or blending or layering or whatever, and then a like to get drunk and sabotage or destroy it.

That way my brain encodes the trauma of having destroyed something that made me happy, while it doesn’t encode the memory of doing it. Causes cognitive dissonance and slows the perception of time. Plus I’m left to look at a painting that hurts my feelings and reminds me of what I was capable of, while hiding evidence of it from anyone else. Bit of a gremlin on the wing scenario but more masturbatory and nihilistically self-indulgent.

Also something about the myth of Sisyphus and we create the rocks we push up a hill or summing idk.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6419142
i think the lack of spine arch is the main problem. arnie is puffing his chest out which comes from arching his mid back really hard. arnie would also have to flex his upper spine (lower neck area) forward to compensate (otherwise it would just look like he's leaning back). this all creates a big S shape in the spine.
liefeld just has his guy standing straight. captain america has the results of the S curve without the S itself. the very stiff legs and hips emphasize this lack of S.
i attached a picture of arnold in the same pose but a more similar perspective to what liefeld used. you can see that the reason why arnold's farside pec sticks out in the OP is because he's angled slightly. he isn't standing perfectly sideways like liefeld thought he was. if arnold was standing squarely sideways like captain america, you would mostly just see one pec. arnold *pretends* like he's standing sideways but he twists his spine to make his chest appear wider and bigger. arnold was very good at posing in these types of ways. liefeld was fooled by it

and then there's the fact that liefeld's guy must have a very short arm behind that shield.

>>6416035
We've had qhd 20"+ tablets for years. And no, it's not overkill to have 4k on a drawing tablet that your face is inches from. Qhd on a 24" is only barely higher ppi than 1080p on a 20".
1440p on a 24" display is 122 ppi, 1080p on a 20" is 110.
If you know fuck all about pixel density, to give you a frame of reference, the 12.9" iPad pro has 264 ppi, and your average phone now has over 500.

posts.com: I recently started drawing or trying to learn a little bit more properly. Around 5-6 weeks I'd say. I used to draw as a kid but I never gave it a serious try, I always gave up and never kept at it. A few weeks ago I had a massive need and motivation to draw so I've been keeping at it, doing a little bit of gesture drawing, form drawing, poses, breaking down body parts/references into smaller parts and trying to understand them. I'm doing a lot of quick drawings from quick poses and after that having fun drawing characters I like I want to get more volume in, have more mental "references". At the end of the day generic cute anime girls are my main motivation to draw(not everything), but I want to get better, I want to be able to do what I want.

>>6411492
Depends on where you’re at, skill-wise and what your goals are. But in order from when I started to now, some books I’ve found helpful are:
Vilppu drawing manual, along with the video lectures
Simultaneously, The first 10-20 pages of any book on perspective to give you a rough idea of 1,2 ,3 point perspective to aid you in the goal of drawing boxes using intuition.
Hampton
Anatomy for sculptors
That Tom fox anatomy book is pretty cool.
And lots of copying art from your favourite artists. And lots of figure drawing.

>>6421987
For muscled figure i used morpho muscled bodies, delavier "strength anatomy training", and "how to draw strong muscles" as study books. I also read medical anatomy textbook, mainly for origin and insertion of muscles in conjunction with morpho skeleton & bone reference points.
As for the refs i use bodybuiling magazine and studio photo from google and pinterest as they show the forms clearly.

Previous thread:
>>6345123

Do Art Daily:
>Link: https://dad.gallery
>Discord: You must have a DAD streak of at least 14 to join. Ask Vastian#0988 for an invite.
>Found an issue with the site? Lost your streak and want to appeal? Please message the contact link at the bottom of the site instead of posting in the thread.

Rules:
>Draw every day (or your preferred frequency)
>Submit your work by 23:59:59 GMT
>Spend at least 30 minutes on each submission
>No loli or shota porn
>Miss a day and you'll be alright, just keep going!
>Maintain your streak and you too can become the LAST ARTIST STANDING!!
>Have fun!

Go and comment on each other's artwork; dads love attention!

FAQ:

What is the goal?
>To form a habit of drawing. The gains you make are dependent on you.

I am /beg/gar and not know draw, can I join?
>Yes x99. Stop asking and start submitting art, chum. Make something!

How long does it take until my account is approved?
>Between two to three weeks, usually when you reach level 3. Even unapproved submissions count toward your streak!

A brief history:
>Last Artist Standing (LAS): The original site, created by Lava (presumed dead, rest in peace). It has changed and ruined the lives of many lassies.
>Draw Every Day (DED): A short-lived site between LAS and DAD, run and abruptly cancelled by w.
>Do Art Daily (DAD): The current site, by the dadmin and developer banana.

Community links:
>DADcast: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCfCw_buGoBDPQC1bbcukmnQ
>LAS discord (alternative to DAD discord): https://discord.gg/5777rZnqW9

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6414342
Here's how I feel about it after using it myself:
>3 to 5 minutes per 1024x1024 image on low end GPU
>10 seconds to 1 minute 30 seconds per 1024x1024 image on med/high end GPU
>Generates bad/unusable results 50-95% of the time depending on the prompt you're using.
>Images have spaghettis fingers 99% of the time.
>There is ALWAYS something wrong with the image, it'll NEVER be perfect.
>Doesn't truly understand what its doing so it ends up making basic perspective errors and lighting/shadow errors that can be a bit harder to notice if you don't have a good eye, but you might notice that something is off.
>Normies view it as low quality/low effort cuz its been used to flood every fandom, drowning out genuine content in the process and its gradually being banned across multiple communities.
>Can't be copyrighted.
>Will be heavily regulated by the government for security reasons. China already passed new laws and more will follow.
It'll be a useful tool to install on our android waifu assistant bots in the distant future. But I won't use my waifu bot to print ai images, I'll just rootkit her and install a sexbot program.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6414342
I had a MJ subscription for 4 months. My conclusions:
>Not good for finished pieces.
>Have to experiment a lot to get good results.
>If you have a specific vision, best to draw it yourself.
>Sometimes it will surprise you with cool stuff, even better than you imagined, but again, takes a lot of experimentation to get there.
>"Prompt crafting" involves having a good knowledge of art styles, artists, techniques, describing in detail, etc. Since I'm into art history (took classes) and writing, I was pretty good at prompting. Still, the results are inconsistent.
>It's best used to create assets for future works. Think of it as a copyright free reference library. To me this is the most practical use of it for artists at this point.
After a while it just became a distraction from drawing, which is a better use of time. I also started to have ethical issues with it after learning more about it.
But on a purely practical level artists are screwing themselves over if they become dependent on it, best to develop your own style for branding purposes. And it's more efficient to communicate through drawing than leaning on an algorithm that spits out random imagery.

Those two points don't even make a line, the copyright talk is because
1.)Artist's works, as well as countless photographs and other images under copyright being used by ML algorithms for commercial purposes, which there is grounds for dispute for, or else Stability AI wouldn't have pussed out and used only non copyrighted music to train its music generator.
2.)If it can be ruled that using copyrighted images in ML image generation, then they will be irrevocably crippled. Without the LAION dataset that it was trained on, SD is dead. You have to have absolutely ENORMOUS amounts of data to train these ML models on to get the results we have today, in fact the "advancements" we have had recently aren't because of a fundamental change in the design of ML models, it's merely because they were able to get their hands on stupid amounts of data to train on. Thus this is one, if not the most vital issue to focus on.
I mean, I'm not sure how you expect anyone to solve the issue of the AIpocalypse without actually, you know, stopping it somehow.

Pretty much if you use Stable Diffusion. Midjurney tries to be creative for you by secretly adding prompts on your images and searching actively for artefacts. Though as a result you have less control over the image output. It is both more pro artist as it is impossible to use for anything useful, but also anti artist as it is too independent and self reliant. You saw these posts online about people asking chatGPT to give them Midjurney prompts and they got really good results? Well, if you strap random word generator to midjurney, it ironically produces better results then human promoters. Everyone in this thread should try to make discord account and generate few pictures of what you want, and then pictures from random word generator. Don’t forget to include “—v 4” at the end. Prompters are unironically done. Also I am not shilling, you get like 25 pictures for free with new account, so you can just leech off of their servers for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6418310
You can’t have advanced AI and not replace most if not all humans. It’s like wanting to have developed coal-based economy and not have any smog. AI is program running on any computer that can do cognitive and informational tasks, but it also has very human design in its creation. Relying more on self thought probabilistic abstract connections instead of being line of code that is executed and has predictable outcomes. It is uniquely capable of doing any work human brain can do. Even the AI researchers themselves try to use it in just the good ways, but then stumble, make offshoot model like image generator from object recognition algorithm, and then the innovation suddenly drives itself. Steering the wheel in AI development is impossible, just some things will work and some won’t. Either way to not replace humans completely, you need to find them niche that machines can’t do. Until now the biggest niche was analysing information, decision making and creativity, all of which can be now replaced by AI.

Just do whatever makes you happy and fuck those social media niggers.

>>6355614
animation is really fuckin difficult, and lots of people tend to write about animation to make it more understandable to beginners and professionals. no single book will be able to cover every possible expression within the medium, so there tends to be a lot of useful resources.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6362663
>>6362664
trace over your key drawing really really carefully. sculpt your lines with smaller strokes and use the eraser to clean it up instead of trying to wing it in one stroke. boil is usually supposed to be really subtle, so keep the onion skin on, flip between frames often, and make sure that nothing is too chaotic as it moves. think of it like you're inbetweening something that's BARELY moving at all. when you turn on the onion skin, you'd want your drawings to practically be on top of one another
boiling also tends to work best on 2s and 3s for general acting, but if you're animating a shiver/shake, then 1s usually fits a lot better.

another thing that i completely forgot about that somehow i've taken for granted is that in TVpaint you can press enter to repeat your last action on the canvas. so if you fuck up drawing a line on the wrong layer, want to repeat a selection, it puts whatever you just made down again. if you select a range of frames it works across them all too with one press, so you can fill an entire animation with colour in one keyboard press. fucking revolutionary and i don't know why other art programs don't have it.

some other things, you can stretch an entire length of animation to re-time it and keep it proportionally intact. also custom brushes, you can cut out an animation and use it as a stamp / animated brush, saves a fuck load of time, and it's incorporated simply into your usual brush tool, and intuitive to use. really easy to make your own brushes that way too.

posts.com:
do japanese people use a different numbering system? Studying genga they use even and odd numbers which if looked at through the lens of the american numbering system would mean they animate on ones, but they don't
how do they indicate frame timings?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
Do you have an example, because the Japanese timesheets look normal to me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
>Studying genga they use even and odd numbers
I just assume that's because they primarily animate on 3s and 4s?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
>>6374284

they likely don't think about their 'number system', most animators don't. they just do what's required for the shot to look good, and sometimes you can get away with 4's. the usual method is to animate 24fps then just 'hold' the frames that last longer (2's, 3's, 4's) and on the rare instance you need to have a 1, you put that in. no point in trying to formulise it, use whatever frames work best wherever as long as it times out correctly. say for a movement that starts fast but you want one extra frame in there at the end to bounce back to a stopping point, it's prob gonna be even/odd or vice versa.

i've never worked on a production that wasn't default 24fps despite 95-100% of the project being animated on 2's. and usually, if you have camera moves in an environment, those need to be on 1's or things look choppy as fuck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
might depend on how they use x-sheets. sometimes they have the timing figured out beforehand or write it down as they go, but retiming later on down the pipelines might change it up and make the notes not line up well anyways.
if I'm animating with an assistant/inbetweener and need to guide them, I label keyframes just with a letter, and then use numbers counting up from 1 to label all the places that need inbetweens. it doesn't really have any relation to a x-sheet, just "INB B3-C, favor C" or some shit like that

good rule of thumb is to know the difference between a "jumping" ball and a "bouncing" ball. a jumping ball sticks to the ground a bit longer and has way more time to squash and stretch, whereas an actual bouncing ball analogous to reality will only be on the ground for a single frame. jumping balls are typically what most non-animator animation purists would see and worship thinking it's what everybody SHOULD do, but it tends to be too over-exaggerated to be useful in many situations. a bouncing ball shouldn't contact with the ground for too long, especially if it's moving in a specific direction where the speed has to slowly roll off with every bounce.
I animated a small representation of what either looks like bouncing in place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6384158
>12fps is the lowest the human eye perceives something as a smooth motion but I don't know if that's broscience.
Definitely bro science. If you learn to look for jitter you can notice it at up to very high framerates, and if you are immersed in a story it's hard for the framerate to screw it up so long as you establish a convention. Only when framerate changes does it force attention away from the story. Appeal > technical skill and effort. Appeal in still art is difficult, appeal in motion harder still. It has to do with how long each frame is held, but it is not just more frames is better.

>What's the lowest frame rate I could generally get away with without it looking like shit
if you're working at 24FPS, you could go all the way down to 4s [6FPS] for slower movements and the average viewer wouldn't even notice. for faster motions and high-paces scenes, it's probably best to go to 2s and 1s. for general character acting and dialogue, 2s, and 3s is alright in most cases, unless you're working with really wild acting and fast speaking.

Thank you very much anon.
In return I'll give some general advice for the thread

Heavily work on your key poses. Yeah I know it's obvious but It's very easy to just add more and more frames because it's very simple to line test with softwares. Plan the animation your head and in advance VERY carefully. "Fluidness" isn't the point in animation, the clarity of each pose and action is what matters most. you don't do a dozen unecessary movements at all times just for the sake of it (ding ding every wannabe amateur webgen animators in twitter)
Not saying it shouldn't ever be done, but you should know the rules before you bend and break them.
Don't hesitate to act the movement yourself as well. FEEL the movement.

posts.sub: A way to prevent artists' work from getting included in future AI models?
posts.com:
The success of these AI tools seem to be driven by their ability to view/collection millions, billions of light-weight images. Mostly with Common Crawl currently.
If it's made much more complicated/intensive to obtain the image via a script at scale, I wonder if that could successfully counter these tools?

On someone's own site they could maybe provide a robots.txt file. But if artists want to use popular social media sites that aren't using that, would uploading their work as videos with some sort of canned intro to prevent thumbnailing be a good deterrent? People could maybe train models off shitty screen-captures in the video, but maybe it could still help prevent scraping at scale.

I wonder if artists should stop posting their art in popular image formats. Maybe a new image format could be made that can't be read easily by these third-party tools.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6421817
Renaissance masters learned to draw from imagination because they wanted to portray fantastical scenes and figures in action. They couldn't take a snapshot or pull up a 3D model of someone soaring through the air.
Comic book artists like Hal Foster, Burne Hogarth and John Buscema had to churn out ungodly numbers of pages under deadline. If they had to stop and find a reference for every pose, they'd never get the work done.
Imagination and memory have to be trained. You try to draw something without reference and discover the gaps in your knowledge. Then you go fill those gaps by studying from life. Repeat. Eventually you'll be able to draw that something without reference.
Beyond just knowledge about how something is put together, it's important to understand perspective and form, and to have a method of building up a drawing regardless of subject matter.

posts.sub: How do you find soul inbetween beg and fundies?
posts.com:
Serious question. I’ve been practicing drawing for over a decade now, have developed various styles but the feeling of soul has somewhat eluded me.

See artists like picrel that ooze so much soul and childlike wonder, yet still grasp just enough of the fundies so that it doesn’t collapse in on itself. They’ve somehow found the balance between fundamentals and total beginner, achieving the stability of the former, while keeping the magic of the latter.

How is this done? Is it accidental? Did they just not learn enough fundies to kill the ‘magic’ of beginner expression? Why do some artists work ooze messy expression and soul while most are overwrought and clinical?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>total beginner
Anon, loose lines and rough shapes doesn't mean beg.
You can see it's done more than less on purpose.
>how to do it
Draw fast, loose lines with a non-sharp pencil.
Check your proportions, especially the head.
Heads on "children picture book-esque" styles tend to be 2 to 3 times bigger relative to the body.
Expression are comical and facial features are exaggerated and rounded up.
The pencil on paper also adds more to the "unclean" style,
Washed out brownish colors also make this style complete.
At least that's how i would approach to learn how to replicate it at first.

There's a common misconception on here that technical gains eliminate soul. But there are plenty of pros who have mastered fundies and still ooze soul. Robert Crumb is one. Kim Jung Gi is another.
A better word than 'soul' might be authenticity. Artists like Crumb and KJG draw what they want and communicate fluently through their tools.

If you want to be able to draw things with "soul" draw more from your imagination and keep learning fundies. The important part is to not stay in your comfort zone.

There definitely is a knowledge of anatomy. The proportions are pleasing and indicate that the artist can just draw figures like this off the cuff. If you don't know anatomy making pleasing stylized figures with pleasing proportions and linework is quite difficult.

Just because you know the fundies doesn't mean you have to be over polishing every sketchbook doodle you make. Choosing when to utilize certain skills and when not to is more a sign this artist knows what they are doing since they are able to do this and have taste. The heart of stylization in general is this practice.

I would recommend trying to draw with just a pen on paper. This really simplifies what you can work with and forces you to utilize fundies as simply as possible.

Building visual library over time. The ability to recall things you’ve previously drawn or seen and being able to confidently build a form from what you recall. Not physically trying to picture the subject in your head like the apple demonstration, but physical attributes you can remember how to draw from last time you did it. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some ways to bridge the gap:
-look at a ref, take it away, draw what you remember, check it against the ref, correct
-pick a pose or scene ref, then draw some OC or existing character in the pose, or draw the scene in some different style
-pick a scene ref, sketch the scene, then add some new detail or object from imagination
-draw a figure from reference, then draw a figure from imagination beside it i\on the same plane
-doodle as many of the simplest, most gestural figures you can manage, in whatever poses come to mind - if they fall apart halfway through and turn into aimless scribble, whatever, do another one
-either buy a well-articulated artist's mannequin or digital 3D posing model, and manipulate it as much as possible, trying to get to where you have some approximation of a posable model in your mind

Also, as dumb as it sounds, be confident. Just come up with what you want to draw, and start drawing as best as you can.

>>6420701
Don't think of it as drawing from imagination. Think of it as drawing from memory. Find something around your house and draw it. Then immediately, go in another room and draw it by remembering what you saw/drew. compare. If you're off by more than 50% pick something easier next time. Do this exercise a lot.

What will happen is you will learn not just the mental operation of recall, but also to make it easier for your future self by observing and making mental notes of the most important visual features. Then you learn to do this when looking at anything you want to draw in the future.

But you must practice this every day or the mental muscle will not build.

I start off either with a bean or a trapezoid for the torso and turn it into a precise and coherent 3d shape. Then I add flat shapes for neck and limbs and slowly work myself through carefully connecting them with bracketing and flesh them out afterwards. It takes a little longer that way, but in the end it's 15 times faster because I don't have to do endless corrections afterwards. What's great about it is it finally lets me control the bendyness of the torso like I want to, and having a clear direction where the arms are in 3d space. Here's my practice sheet from today exploring a little more.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6367918
Depends on the colors and obviously on the pigment, let's just say that even on artist grade gouache they're very liberal with their lightfastness grading. Traditional gouache was never meant to be archival, it doesn't form a film once it dries, it's chalky and gets dirty fast unless you put it under glass, it's was meant for illustrators to quickly turn their artwork, photograph it for publishing and forget about it.
General speaking you should worry about the pinks but there are colors that people not suspect like raw sienna and yellow ochre, they will get grayer, unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Even acrylic will shift, I have Golden Fluid Yellow Ochre and it shifted to gray months later. Any color that looks saturated and vibrant won't stay that way for long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6367918
>Is artist grade Gouache worth it?
Yes. You'll get more pigment, smoother grind, better flow, single-pigment colours (better mixing), less fillers (more vibrant). Schmincke is great, and I can wholly recommend. Just get a few tubes of artist-grade instead of a bunch of chinesium.

>I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?
Water-soluble, so thinning with water works. You'll only need mediums if you want to thin it a ton, since super-thinned paint films are not necessarily durable. Other than that you can pretty much paint on anything. It's essentially coloured plastic.

There's like a million mediums that you won't need but that could be nice, like thickeners, thinners, drying time extenders, crackling, more shine, less shine, flow improvers, etc. You can make a frankenpaint to your specific liking if you really want to tinker with it.

>>6368450
As said in last thread, Mont Marte probably does not manufacture their own stuff and commission random (see: cheapest) manufacturer to make stuff they just repackage. Sometimes you can get decent stuff, but it really is playing art supply gacha.

HIMI Jelly Gouache is significantly better, and honestly a pretty decent quality paint. I would recommend Holbein, if that's available in your neck of the woods.

>>6368722
>unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Holbein, WN, Schmincke Horadam, and M. Graham all make Gouache without the addition of whiteners, relying on pure pigment density to get opacity. Any of these will work. It's notable that Holbein is by far the cheapest, at least in EU, and Schmincke pigment is very finely ground so it's less opaque than the others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372118
chalk/marble dust (can extend pigments in oil; use for making paint transparent for glazing in oil; traditional glue chalk ground is less expensive than ready-made acrylic ground and dry components store longer; use as opacifier in gouache)
rabbit skin glue/hide glue (used for grounds, sizing; distemper medium; glue for attaching canvas to board)
metal point (small piece lasts very long; brass can be found for free, or buy/find wire that lasts many life times over; some can fit into a clutch pencil; can coat scrap wood with chalk and or some other ground of your choice in weak glue size and reuse board for scrap drawings, by recoating or scraping)
charcoal powder (can be made for free; decent for ink with suitable binder ground finely; good for paint; use for tracing; many other uses)
egg (yolk and pigment for egg tempera, good for lean underpainting for oil paint or as a cheap and durable paint, don't need entire yolk; can make water-miscible paint by adding to oil paint, thin and clean with water instead of solvents; glair, made by whipping egg white and letting liquid separate from foam, can be used as paint or ink binder; adjust strength with distilled water; can be dried by pouring in a shallow container and letting sit, dissolve again by water; supposedly aged wet, not too tightly sealed glair is better; can be modified by adding honey or sugar etc; used in some varnish recipes; can be use in metal point grounds)

>>6372834
None if you use inks, if not then the film isn't strong enough to adhere to the other layers, should be fine if you're just staining the paper. Use gesso, it will create blooms like watercolor.

Too much water will upset the balance and spread the acrylic polymer too thinly so the molecules can't reconnect properly to form a stable film. Instead you should dilute with an acrylic medium, which is essentially the same as the paint but without the color pigment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

>>6394737
it's not an alternative to thinners. it's more of an alternative to fluid and gel mediums like sunthickened linseed oil or maroger medium. while thinners lower the oil content, fluid and gel mediums increase the oil content.
one should not use too much thinner because pigments lose binder.
one should not use too much fluid/gel medium because the pigments have too much binder and can cause problems like wrinkling or yellowing depending on the medium.

G pen is good option if you don't like fineliner. Maru nibs is an option for thinner lines. Dip pen need a lot of practice and kinda messy at first. Stick with Japanese brands.
Also try to use brush and ink, the only problem is they can't really use waterproof ink, otherwise it's pretty flexible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

>>6404987
to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

posts.com:
>>6415758
there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415075

The sets are bad, you're paying a lot for hues that don't play well together.

Only get the SKETCH markers, not the Classic or Ciao. Start with a cool/neutral/warm gray set depending on your style and needs, they can be used as a base with other hues.

Then buy a set of singles with similar color intensities and ID's. Check this guide to make sense of the ID system: https://markernovice.com/copic/copic-numbering

If you're going for realism you're not going to want all the intense candy shades, plus that the hue samples usually look lighter than they'll end up on your paper/pad after several strokes, and a lot of the really lighter shades (X000 etc) can be used to mix with other hues for great effect.

So for a range of blues you might want B21 Baby Blue, B91 Night Blue, B37 Antwerp Blue, B61 Light Hydrangea, instead of the intense ones like B29 Ultramarine, B16 Caynine Blue or B06 Peacock Blue. You can easily get by with a set of 3-4 in each hue range, some skintones, some ultralights, which might amount to 20 or so markers total. A lot cheaper than 72 goofball hues that don't blend well.

You'll get a blender with a gray set but it's not what you think, blending is done by carefully connecting two adjacent hues and not with the blender marker, it's more of an FX thing that'll wet your strokes and turn them abit watercolory.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6419617
Learn about the parts of shadows and about reflected light. Usually, if you have one surface sitting on another, the inner part of the shadow takes on some of the color and reflected light of the surface it’s sitting against - in this case, blue. As the object’s shape turns back towards the main light source, it picks up more of the surrounding environment, and you can emphasize this in a stylistic way by adding a bit more of saturated version of the main light source’s color - in this case, orange. Pic shows the parts of the shadow. The blue here is in the reflected area, and the orange is in the half tone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416749
(Clockwise order)
So-bin
Murata
Atmosphere sketchbooks has sketches from I think 3 artists
Settei Dreams has artbooks and storyboards of anime
Horikoshi has sketches
And Inoue Kiyoshirou has an "artbook" which is just the sketches of a hentai he drew.

In the end, you won't find many "artbooks" like the yoshinari one especially of artists' sketches. Mostly finished work which you said you're not looking for.
Also, don't limit to just artbooks, copy directly from manga too.(Which is how most mangakas got good.) since they're basically just clean sketches

Lastly, don't hoard books, I recommend copying front to back 1 at a time before moving onto the next one every single week.
Hope I helped ;)

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416988
Depending on how strong your fundamentals are, it will extend your understanding of them. If you don't know perspective then you can't understand how the artist is playing with perspective. Master studies are typically done to see how a specific artist solved a problem. There is a big difference between how a sculptor solves painting clothing folds and a comic artist and a painter and one or all of them may be compatible with the style you inevitably end up with but you won't know unless you do the studies to begin with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
that's better moot

>BUT WHY SHOULD I DO GESTURE DRAWINGS INSTEAD OF JERKING OFF ON e621 AND PLAYING VIDYA?
gesture drawing is the squat of drawing exercises. when you do a gesture drawing you practice proportion, shapes, line economy, value control, anatomy (for longer studies 5+ min), relationship between parts, and foreshortening. it also makes your poses more dynamic because it gives you and understanding of body weight and movement.
in addition, you exercise your ability to draw from memory since you don’t have lot of time, you have to quickly take in and capture essence of a pose. you will also get better at drawing figures from imagination.

if you don’t do 10 minutes of gesture drawing today your mother will die in her sleep tonight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
see if this artist or artists like them have uploaded process videos, study that
choose any small arbitrary square inside of the image (the purple crystal on the staff would be a good start) and see if you can render something that looks just like it. experiment until you have a method that works
draw draw draw x 100000

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: hard round brush

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There is no other way than doing a study, so try to imitate it as well as possible. Yes you will fail at first and it will look nothing like what you want, but you'll keep getting better and this also usually gives you serious gains. If I can give you some hints/advice, it seems lineart and colors are done on one layer. It's also what I'm doing and this adds a lot to the "painterly" look. You block out the shape and then paint lineart on top, lighten/darken layer modes are helpful. Don't trace the lineart like >>6418909 is suggesting because that is not the workflow here

posts.com:

>>6418937
Basically, to clarify, you don't do clean lineart on one layer + colors underneath for this kind of artstyle so don't even try that, you won't achieve this look that way. Block out the shapes and then shade them. Again, I use lighten/darken for an extremely similar artstyle so I recommend giving it a try. Seems to be a tetradic color palette but I'm not 100% sure as I usually don't use it, I'm a slave to split complementary

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6366575
>spend more than 10 minutes
All my drawing attempts are agonzingly slow as I spend ages deliberating every single line. I can't imagine getting something done in only ten minutes.
>pick an easier subject
I genuinely don't understand what supposedly makes a subject easier or harder to draw. Everything past basic geometric shapes/forms seems impossibly difficult. I've seen people claim that rocks and trees are easy, which seems crazy to me given that they have such incredibly complex shapes and textures.
>copy literal lines and squares that you drew
I can copy drawings without much issue. The difficulty of drawing for me isn't in measuring or line placement, but in figuring out how the subject could be depicted as a drawing in the first place. I don't have an intuitive understanding of what I'm supposed to be marking with lines, or a clear idea of what process people actually use to draw things. I can also never mentally picture what a drawing of any particular subject would look like. As such, there's very little actually guiding my efforts, which is presumably why I always end up with bizarre indecipherable scribbles.

>>6367712
I had similar problem, but I generally solve it in the canvas, and I let fuck ups ignite more ideas, if I can't picture it, time to look at refs and do some iterations. A good exercise is picking an object like a banana, observe it for a minute, notice the contours, textures, distinctive shapes, now get rid of the banana and draw it as you recall, take your time. Now a copy of it now, check the differences between the 2 drawings.

Some cheap workaround for coming up with something is creating a square in an isometric angle, and just put stuff some simple subjects in it, or you can do it with wonky perspective, but keep a basic angle of view, use your room as reference if you want. Like looking at your desk and pretend that's a little village you're looking at. If you're autistic you can make dioramas too. Also try sculpting, even plastiline is good enough, it's just to start to get you thinking spatially, you need to develop that awareness to think above just abstract lines into a white void, if you need an extra push rely on reference for ideas and details.
Even for awareness you need awareness, it's not just about aping things, but being present, if you have different perspectives you've got yourself better odds at solving problems in your art process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only "masteries" are

>line quality

>Perspective

>Anatomy

>Values


Line quality is the best to learn first, deciding what's thick and what's thin, using lines to imply the shape instead of perfectly tracing it out. Anatomy is next, its just measurements. The head is as complex as the entire body, but the key is consistency. Perspective is being able to rotate what you drew and draw it in another angle, usually a more interesting one. Values are colors and shading.

There are things like composition which I would call a mastery but its something you can learn the entire time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I will translate the OP's chart into words for you autists, with some additional neg levels:

level -2: cant draw lines of any sort , and cannot draw shapes
level -1: can draw lines and simple shapes
level 0: multiple shapes that look human, but fill no 3d space and are not proportional
level 1: proportional and symmetrical
level 2: a minimum understanding of 3d space
level 3: a more complex pose (limited to frontal, 3/4 view, profile)
level 4: Even more complex pose, includes other normal viewing angles - any angle that is not frontal, 3/4, or profile, more subtle control elements.
level 5: Starting to add more extreme perspective control - frogs eye view, birds eye, ants eye, fish eye, perspective and scenery
level 6+: impossible to tell from a single image - history of being "in control of style" with the ability to duplicate/replicate whatever styles the person likes.

Also take the other chart that goes with that one.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

I'm still doing drawabox. After lesson 1 there's the 250 BC which I finished, then obviously it gets more complicated from there so I take it slower. I started with 0 still (we all do) and did not enjoy drawing at all and therefore couldn't improve at all. Getting through even just L1/250BC from Drawabox forced my brain to consider perspective and forced my hand to make clean lines, Loomis' cartoons and simple constructions granted more imagination so now drawing is an actual hobby and not a daunting thing. Personally going to move on from a Loomis' stuff and when I feel good either start trying to learn from a Scott Robertson book or CGMA dynamic drawing course, idk.

posts.com:
I don't have all the answers, but I have one area that I think would be beneficial.

Social media detox.

It's hard when you actually try to not log in. In my case, I deleted my Twitter (which was the main site where I was obsessed with my numbers) account years ago, and it was one of the best decisions I made.
No more obsessing over some other person, and using the time I browsed social media to watch another movie/show... Play some games (I don't recommend competitive online multiplayer as that is another rabbit hole that will destroy your productivity and sanity)

The more you detach yourself from the source of frustration (in your case, this other dude) the better you will be in terms of personal sanity.. Which leads to making more healthy overall choices in life. Which then leads to a hopefully more enjoyable drawing experience.

Because the best way to improve is actually enjoying the stuff you're doing.
Instead of, 'Fuck! I need to be better.' and feeling anxious, hopefully you can start feeling like, 'Oh hell yeah, I'm gonna be drawing some fun shit!'

Jealousy is a poison that is hard to rid of, anon. Wishing you the best!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6417642
I understand how you feel OP. My friend and I would trash other people's stuff and criticize them to high hell, especially if they were assholes. Then something hit me, no matter how I feel about their stuff and or them as a person..they are actually putting work out there and the more stuff they put out there the more they end up improving...because they are actually working on art and taking chances.

People don't care how good it really is...if you have been out there slugging it out for a while people will come. The more stuff you release, the more people you get to know, and the more chances you take...the more you will grow. This will result in more opportunities coming your way. That's a big part of how luck works.

So, instead, look to them as your rival and take whatever lessons you can from them and work on yourself and your own work. Focus on yourself and improve. Create your own network. If you are even on slightly good terms with that person reach out and keep things friendly with them. You don't have to lick their asshole clean, but you never know what can happen.

Once I stopped focusing on others and focused on myself and my own work...I finally have some regular clients and in negotiations for some projects in the future.

Meanwhile, my friend who was having some success ended up quitting art and found a lot more success elsewhere. Coincidentally, in the field that they are in now, they seem to not be nearly as judgmental or critical of the people they work with or in their field. Instead they focused on themselves and improved their own skills, too.

That's the best advice I can give you.

It's actually really simple. Pass legislation that says " any creative content produced through the use of artificial intelligence, isn't protected by trademark or copyright in any way. And cannot be sold for profit."

Someone makes a game, movie, book, comic, t-shirt, etc... using AI, and starts to sell it for profit. Congratulations, it's not protected by AI and is effectively considered public domain, thus, anyone can 1:1 rip your product and sell it as well, earning you essentially no viable product licencing or monetary benefit.

This ensures no company will ever try to use AI to skirt around having to hire real human artists to do the job. You want copyright protection? Then you must prove you paid real human artists to create the work. If anything, the copyright process should get more strict, and require proof that it was made without AI in order to be able to file for copyright protection.

Now tech bros get to play with their little toy, but it's no longer a viable tool commercially, ensuring creative jobs are protected.

The Indy guy can now make his shitty comic book without hiring an artist if they want, but their IP isn't eligible for copyright protection unless they pay someone to draw it for them, etc... It seems like a fairly reasonable and simple solution to sort out this entire mess to me.

I don't think you understand what I mean. Say I design a character, and decide that I want to modify it to suit a certain vibe.

Say I want to take the design language found in something thoroughly contrasting, but incorporate it in a way that suits what's established there. An artist can do this, an artist can see "hey, the seals found in Space Marines in Warhammer are cool and suit the direction of what I'm doing" or "I wanna add more belts like in Final Fantasy" an artist can apply these ideas specifically, abd use them to modify the design in ways that work more organically. An AI doesn't really "get this. I doesn't understand design concepts like empty space or concentrated detail to lead the eye, and it often fumbles detail. You say "add Warhammer spikes" or whatever, abd it's gonna bruteforce it and create a monstrosity, whereas a real person is more effectively able to imagine their design as a real thing, and give it a certain sense of function and logical consistency. It's also able to pull from real life inspiration, and modify those ideas in ways that blend with what they're making. AI, cannot do this at all. It totally sucks on the design front. And compositionally, it's also very cookie cutter. It seems to prefer certain compositional styles over others, and really struggles hard with certain types of perspective.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6421227
>Is the machine the artist or is it a tool?
It's *both*

In the case of AI, it's the artist in that it defines what is ultimately presented in the final product. It's the tool in that it takes in the operator's input and processes it in a way that creates a useful output based on the operator's input. In the case of the tablet, it's the artist in that it automates and defines elements of the artwork that most people don't even think about, including color, shape, and texture. All of these are 1s and 0s sitting in your device's writable memory, and their presentation is ultimately completely defined by the machine itself. It's the tool in that it won't define these things unless the artist tells it to.

I'm not even against artists, by the way. I think the retards who want to bury you for wanting to protect your craft are all a waste of space who also don't actually understand the technology they worship.

I think the intellectual property being used against your will aspect is probably your best bet in pushing legislation. The problem with this is that artists essentially freely give out their artwork on twitter, pixiv, deviantart, etc. None of these sites actually protect your work using DRM or anything like the big boys at Netflix and Amazon do to make the files they provide to end users harder to steal.

It's hard to argue that an artist didn't want their work to be used in a certain way when they basically gave away infinite copies of it on the twitter street corner. What's to stop another traditional artist from heavily using their style, given that the artwork was given away for free with no strings attached?

I guess I think that you don't have a warranty for anything you release to the public on twitter. So you can't really have a say in how your art gets used if you give it away like that. If the art used to train these things is something you've privately given to friends, or something you've charged money for (on fanbox, etc) that isn't public, then yes I think you would have the right to tell the model trainers to fuck off.

His point is that the machine will create something as soon as you run the program, with or without your input. And you can't "actively" change what it puts out, you can only influence it. Copyright laws exist for a reason. I can't just take the design for Mickey Mouse and use it to create an original character just because it's "out there". The problem is that laws have not caught up to the tech yet and we are living in the Wild West of ai art. The other problem is that there is so much copyrighted shit in the training data that the programs would probably be useless without it. The main reason why they got so "good" in the first place is because they were trained on very large databases. This is why aicels get so mad whenever people suggest that they should not just be able to train on copyrighted data without permission.

>>6421973
I think it's fair to at least try and slow it down. It gives people time to consider their options and re-specialize if necessary.

I do think artists should be focusing more on ways to prevent their data from getting automatically scraped. We desperately need a site that is hostile to AI art and to scrapers.

A new professional artist gallery website would need the following:

An anti-AI detection system that prevents AI images from being uploaded
An anti-scraping mechanism that makes it hard for images to be scraped from the site.

It would probably not be too hard to create the first, given the sheer volume of AI-generated images currently in circulation. The second might require different techniques - perhaps slicing an image up into various different images in a way that isn't immediately visible could be a solution to this problem, and the way the images would be sliced would be random. That way, any automated scraping of the site would be difficult at best. Randomized invisible watermarks should be present as well. Blocking right clicking and inspect element should also be done to weed out the less tech-savvy scrapers.

>>6421555
This. Scarcity is central to the concept of value. Humans have limited lifespans and limited time to build skills. So it's impressive when someone invests those resources and is able to achieve great results. If you pump out thousands of AI generated pictures in a few days, the value of every single one of those pictures is going to be minuscule compared to true, human-made masterpieces.

Obviously this line of thinking doesn't apply equally everywhere. Just like most people buy mass-produced furniture nowadays, plenty of people will be content with consuming AI art. But it will always be the "cheap version" of art.

People pay because they can't make it by themselves.
If you could simply summon a burger in your hand, would you ever order a burger?

The reason you don't see yourself buying art is because you don't think there is anyone supplying what you need.
You either have a very specific vision of how things should be, and won't trust anybody else to reach that look for you, OR you enjoy solving the problem and creating the art more than you enjoy the result.

But not your customers, they want the picture and they don't want/can't invest all the hours necessary to actually get good at it.

I for one enjoy getting fanart or even doing art trades, but dislike the idea of buying, because for me art of my characters is either something personal, which I know best how to do, or something emotional, that a friend/fan should create out of his own volition, not as a job.

>>6420117
In short, because art makes us feel things by connecting us with our own experiences through the art piece itself.

Recently I found a box of old Loony Tunes baseball cards with unique baseball themed cartoon drawings of Bugs Bunny throwing pitches, Marvin the Martian at bat, etc. I fell in love. The illustrations were lively and it felt like I was watching the old cartoons again.

Art makes people FEEL. It does things to them. It makes them feel things they don’t normally get to feel. I recently saw a professional photo someone posted here on IC of a young woman (picrel) who had an expression on her face like she had just lost a loved one and I immediately felt melancholy flood my whole being. I then wanted that piece hanging in my house, because of how it made me feel inside.

This is what beautiful things do to people. They take us to familiar places that we dont usually get to go to on our own. It typically isn’t without seeing the beautiful thing (art) that will then serve as a vehicle or portal to that familiar experience that we have inside of us - a place we want to visit again and again.

Perhaps you just haven’t experienced this yet. Perhaps you need to grow a bit older to appreciate the link between art and lived experience. It really is something special, and very different from creating your own art. The piece of art feels valuable, you want it, it means something to you to have it and to be able to see it everyday.

posts.name: Why isn't art fun anymore?
posts.com:
I can draw. I can paint. I can sculpt. I can do art on the level I always wanted to, create literally anything I want. I'm far more flexible than even some of the artists I look up to.

But fuck I hate art now. It's not like it's hard, hell anyone who says this shit is hard clearly just isn't using references. I just don't get it.

It used to be fun to talk to other artists. I used to like designing characters and dreaming up stories for them. I used to genuinely admire other people's art. Now I can't fucking stand artists because they're all whiney self-important cunts and I only ever look at others' art with either harsh judgement or jealousy.

Where did the fun go in this shit? Did art change or did I?

who is this? Your attempt is not terrible. Mostly lacking in various comparable proportion and perspective zones. Digital is how I prefer to practice likenesses because you can notice your mistakes further in the piece and its not over/ easy to correct. But that does not mean one should get lazy with their initial block in of shape.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6404606
This is stylised away in a lot of anime but this shape is a combination of both the curve of the brow bone and the curve of the cheek bone. It gets easier to draw when you stop thinking of it as a protrusion and think of it more as a wedge taken out of the face to fit the eyes. If you look at a face from the side you can actually see they both meet around the outside of the eye socket. From a 3/4 view it's the recession of the eye socket that makes it look more like a ledge or bump.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6404606
Excuse the MS paint mouse drawing, this is not how to start a drawing per se, but a way to conceptualize the head. The plane of the forehead (A) hangs out like a canopy over the plane of the cheeks (C). The transition between the two planes (change in direction of the outline) is at the plane of the eye sockets (B).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6404606
Depending on the rotation of the head, the bump may be the cheek bone, the fleshy part of the cheek, or the jaw. So there is no single correct position, but a range of positions. You are interpolating between features that are themselves variable.
In short, if you try to draw this bump in the same place for every face from every angle, you will fail.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6418738
I agree with this. There’s a difference between always drawing eyes of a certain shape because you have experimented with many shapes and like that one the best, versus always drawing eyes of a certain shape because you once accidentally drew it that way and you don’t know why it looks correct but it’s the only correct-looking type of eye you can produce so you just stick with it. That’s why the bad kind of same face syndrome also usually includes same pose syndrome - the structure of that feature has not been properly understood, it’s just a good looking fluke being repeatedly copied line for line.

Notice that in >>6418721, even though they all look like the same woman, their heads are turned in different directions because he can handle drawing this faces in many poses. He understands it in 3D.

>>6394355
Yeah, I'm really interested in both of them. As well as Rey Bustos's Rey's Anatomy if you ever come around that.

Sadly I can't provide any thorough tips on how to scan a book but contrary to what people have said, I don't think you will destroy the binding of these books if you scanned them. Since these books are hard cover, their have a different, much more flexible and durable binding than your average paperback book.

As much as it is true that you will destroy the binding of a paperback book if you scan them it, hardcover books- those that you are not afraid to open at more then 90° degrees wont really be that damaged.

Something that I have found when doing 3D work is to move every part of the body slightly, even when it's just a part of a degree. It will instantly look more dynamic. Having the legs bent just a slight bit will help with this too, it makes it look like a heavy body is being supported by the legs.Loose arms can do, but it's akin to not knowing where to put your hands during a presentation and looks awkward. Muscular poses can be more straight and stiff, to show off their physique.

Hopefully I was of help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: How do you study from books
posts.com:
I've been filted by all books about drawing I've read.
How does one approach them?
Do you copy the drawings it has? Memorize them? Read then and then try to do it? Doing it while reading it? Using it in real life?

How do you process the information in the books?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410740
1. Make a google document with the name of the subject matter, then the book and teacher's name
2. Write down an explanation of which fundamental the book teaches, why I need to learn it and what my goals wiht it are
3. Divide the book/seminar in weeks or chapters.
4. Read 1 Chapter, write down my own understanding of it in the google document
5. Finish off by giving myself homework on it, and take a snap shot to paste it into said google document
6. Move onto the next chapter and repeat

This is the best way to actually learn on your own, you only truly understand things when you are forced to explain them to yourself in written form, then you are forced to apply it.
-
I am actually doing this exact same thing with that book you just posted. I have to do 100 figures, I got 10 down so far. I gave myself an explanation of the core ideas, from the 8 parts of the body to the rythm, story, balance, weight, CSI lines and the metholodgy applied step by step (Finding the head, then the spine, then into the pelvis using repetition lines that add flow and gesture to it, before placing wrapping lines).
posts.filename: Michael Hampton - Anatomy - Homework 1 - 100 Figure Drawings

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410743
How do you figure out what's the best homework for every chapter?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410744
With that book specifically, its ez because Michael Hampton as a seminar that literally tells you what the homework should be

But as a rule of thumb, you are going to want to draw a shit lot of whatever they actually tried to explain in said chapter.
So, if the chapter is about learning how to use the multiplication/division technique to extend squares as they recede back into space, then you do that exercise 50 times till it becomes ez
If the chapter is about how to render a sphere, then you go and render 100 spheres from as many angles as you can imagine/find in refs

If you are looking for Michael Hamptons homework I can give it to you :o

Here is the homework either way :o


----------------------------------------
Course Description:
As students continue to develop a basic skill set throughout this course, a special emphasis will be placed on the understanding and application of those basics to the human figure. This course will emphasize a process based approach and development of the figure heavy in an analysis of from, construction, and perspective. This course will offer and in depth study of the figure and the surface anatomy while always maintaining a grounding in the artistic and principles of design.
Week 1: Lecture: Introduction of teacher/ Goals of class. Lecture on gesture and the development of a process.

Homework: 100 Gesture Drawings (half should be done from life, the other half from Old Masters drawings, paintings or sculpture). Choose 5 of your best gestures to submit for critique and instructor feedback. Drawings may be scanned in and submitted or submitted as digital files done in photoshop or as jpgs. You may also upload one, or more, for student feedback on the class blog.
Week 2: Lecture: Connections, Shape and Understanding the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 construction drawings. Drawings should follow in class process of gesture, shapes, connections, landmarks, and finally into a development of the perspectives of the torso, arms, and legs. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 3: Lecture: Head Drawing. Construction and design of the human head.
Homework: 25 Head constructions. Following the in class work flow, develop the head from simple shapes into the architectural planes. Development of the features is optional. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback
----

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410753
Week 4: Lecture: Muscles: Torso/trunk. Placing the anatomical shapes of the upper and lower torso based off the understanding of the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Only develop the muscles covered within the lecture, but be sure to draw the entire pose. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 5: Lecture: Torso 2.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Include the muscles discussed in the prior week as well as the anatomy of the torso. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 6: Lecture: Structure and anatomy of the legs
Homework: 25 Leg and pelvis constructions. Include the anatomy on top of the underlying skeletal and perspective breakdowns. Pay close attention to the shape, gesture, and perspective of each shape as you build. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 7: Lecture: The structure, design and anatomy of the upper arm and shoulders.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the upper torso. This week should specifically focus on the shoulder girdle and the muscles of the scapula and front of the humerus. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 8: Lecture: The structure, construction, and design of the forearm.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the forearms. Choose 2 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
---------------------

Thats all of it, save it into a notepad or something :o
